Award.AwardTitle: Predictive Computational Tools for Biomass Fast Pyrolysis in Fluidized Bed Reactors using Particle-Resolved Direct Numerical Simulation of Reacting Gas-Solid Flow

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336941
Subramaniam

The importance of sustainable energy generation from renewable sources that minimizes environmental impact is now globally recognized, and is a national priority. This project focuses on fundamental scientific understanding of reacting gas-solid flows that is needed to overcome technological barriers for the successful development of one such renewable energy source, namely, the production of biofuels. Predictive computational models of biomass fast pyrolysis are needed for large-scale production of biofuel using fluidized-bed reactors. State-of-the-art computational codes for fluidized-bed reactors use simplistic models for average reaction rates as well as heat and mass transfer correlations developed in the late 1970s, which recent research reveals are problematic. To address this shortcoming, high-fidelity direct numerical simulations will be used in this project to gain fundamental understanding of reacting gas-solid flow. This fundamental understanding will result in physics-based models that will be implemented into a popular open-source multi-fluid code MFIX. The improved and validated model for reacting gas-solid flow can be used by industry to evaluate and optimize fluidized-bed reactors for fast pyrolysis of biomass. These improvements will also result in more accurate simulation of fluidized beds for chemical looping combustion and CO2 capture using dry sorbents. The PI has coordinated a successful recruitment and retention program entitled Women in Mechanical Engineering, and both PIs will continue ongoing efforts to train graduate and undergraduate women and minority students as part of this research project.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Predictive computational models of biomass fast pyrolysis are needed for scale-up of fluidized-bed reactors for biofuel production to increase sustainable energy generation from renewable energy sources. Improved models can also optimize CO2 capture from flue gas of power plants in continuous processes using dry sorbents in fluidized bed reactors.

Intellectual Merit: In this project we developed high-fidelity computational methods to perform ground-truth simulations of flow with heat and mass transfer between gas and particles. These simulations are among the first-of-its-kind to provide a highly accurate description of how biomass can be converted by heat into biofuels and other useful products. The project objectives of quantifying flow velocity, temperature and species concentration fields using direct numerical simulation were achieved. This data was then used to develop models of gas-solid heat transfer that were implemented in two-fluid computational fluid dynamics software to simulate biomass fast pyrolysis in a laboratory scale reactor. The models were tested against experimental data and existing models and their behavior was characterized over a range of operating conditions. The research was disseminated in two published journal papers, one journal paper in preparation, five conference papers and six invited talks. One PhD thesis and one Masters thesis were completed by two graduate students as part of the project.

Broader Impact Outcomes: The improved models of heat and mass transfer in gas-solid flow have been implemented into two popular open-source multi-fluid codes for multiphase flow simulation: MFIX (Multiphase Flow with eXchanges) by the National Energy Technology Laboratory and OpenFOAM. These improvements will result in more accurate simulation of fluidized  beds for chemical looping combustion and CO2 capture using dry sorbents. One female graduate student was mentored as part of this research project.

Modified by: Shankar Subramaniam

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Predictive computational models of biomass fast pyrolysis are needed for scale-up of fluidized-bed reactors for biofuel production to increase sustainable energy generation from renewable energy sources. Improved models can also optimize CO2 capture from flue gas of power plants in continuous processes using dry sorbents in fluidized bed reactors. Intellectual Merit: In this project we developed high-fidelity computational methods to perform ground-truth simulations of flow with heat and mass transfer between gas and particles. These simulations are among the first-of-its-kind to provide a highly accurate description of how biomass can be converted by heat into biofuels and other useful products. The project objectives of quantifying flow velocity, temperature and species concentration fields using direct numerical simulation were achieved. This data was then used to develop models of gas-solid heat transfer that were implemented in two-fluid computational fluid dynamics software to simulate biomass fast pyrolysis in a laboratory scale reactor. The models were tested against experimental data and existing models and their behavior was characterized over a range of operating conditions. The research was disseminated in two published journal papers, one journal paper in preparation, five conference papers and six invited talks. One PhD thesis and one Masters thesis were completed by two graduate students as part of the project. Broader Impact Outcomes: The improved models of heat and mass transfer in gas-solid flow have been implemented into two popular open-source multi-fluid codes for multiphase flow simulation: MFIX (Multiphase Flow with eXchanges) by the National Energy Technology Laboratory and OpenFOAM. These improvements will result in more accurate simulation of fluidized  beds for chemical looping combustion and CO2 capture using dry sorbents. One female graduate student was mentored as part of this research project. Last Modified: 12/21/2018 Submitted by: Shankar Subramaniam
